title: John Bolton Ousted by Trump as National Security Adviser
text:
WASHINGTON—President Trump abruptly dismissed his national security adviser, John Bolton, amid a growing split between the president and the hawkish aide on foreign policy.

Mr. Trump said he told Mr. Bolton he was out of a job on Monday night.

“I informed John Bolton last night that his services are no longer needed at the White House. I disagreed strongly with many of his suggestions, as did others in the Administration, and therefore I asked John for his resignation, which was given to me this morning,” Mr. Trump wrote on Twitter on Tuesday.

“I thank John very much for his service. I will be naming a new National Security Advisor next week,” he added.

Mr. Bolton has disagreed with the president on several foreign policy issues—including, most recently, the president’s interest in meeting with Taliban leaders at Camp David to negotiate a possible peace deal in Afghanistan.

In his own Twitter message, Mr. Bolton offered a conflicting account of his departure, saying: “I offered to resign last night and President Trump said, ‘Let’s talk about it tomorrow.’”

Mr. Bolton’s offer to resign came during a contentious conversation with Mr. Trump about Afghanistan on Monday before the president left for a campaign rally in North Carolina, according to a person familiar with the conversation.

Mr. Trump grew frustrated that Mr. Bolton continued to oppose the president’s plan to strike a peace deal with the Taliban and the Afghan government. Mr. Bolton has supported drawing down troops in Afghanistan.

Early Tuesday, Mr. Bolton sent a letter of resignation to the White House, this person said.

Few at the White House expected the resignation. Mr. Bolton was scheduled to brief White House reporters Tuesday afternoon, along with Secretary of State Mike Pompeo and Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin. White House press officials sent a news release about the joint briefing about an hour before Mr. Trump posted on Twitter about his national security adviser’s departure.

Charles Kupperman, the deputy national security adviser, has been named Mr. Bolton’s temporary replacement, a White House spokeswoman said.

Names being discussed by those close to Mr. Trump as potential full-time replacements included Rob Blair, a senior White House official who has been a national security adviser for acting chief of staff Mick Mulvaney, and Ric Grenell, the U.S. ambassador to Germany. Neither immediately responded to a request for comment.

A White House spokeswoman declined to comment on a potential successor, who would be Mr. Trump’s fourth national security adviser in three years.

In their previously scheduled White House press briefing about terrorism-related sanctions—now minus Mr. Bolton—Messrs. Mnuchin and Pompeo deflected questions about the specific drivers of Mr. Bolton’s departure, while saying that foreign leaders shouldn’t take his exit as signaling a shift in U.S. policy.

Mr. Mnuchin noted that Mr. Trump and Mr. Bolton disagreed on the Iraq War, and Mr. Pompeo acknowledged that he often disagreed with Mr. Bolton on policy as well. Asked if he was surprised by Mr. Bolton’s departure, given that Tuesday morning’s public schedule had him attending the briefing, Mr. Pompeo responded: “I’m never surprised.”

National security adviser John Bolton watching as President Trump meets with South Korean President Moon Jae-In in the Oval Office of the White House in Washington on May 22, 2018. Photo: Evan Vucci/Associated Press

Pressed by a reporter if the national security team was a “mess,” Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin responded, “Absolutely not. That’s the most ridiculous question I’ve ever heard of.”

The decision to part ways appeared to be as much about competing personalities and questions about loyalty as it was about opposing viewpoints on the direction of foreign policy.

Messrs. Trump and Bolton had a professional relationship but “not a personal one,” one person said. The two didn’t have the level of chemistry that Mr. Trump has with Mr. Pompeo, for example, the person added.

There also has been tension between Messers. Bolton and Pompeo, but it had grown worse in recent weeks, according to one person familiar with the matter. Meanwhile, Mr. Blair’s role at the White House has been growing in recent weeks under Mr. Mulvaney.

Mr. Blair increasingly has been taking the lead on national security matters at the White House. “He’s in every meeting with the president. Bolton isn’t,” said another person familiar with the matter.

Mr. Bolton, 70, took over as national security adviser on April 9, 2018, about a week before the U.S., France and the United Kingdom carried out a series of military strikes in Syria.

He scored key policy victories during his White House tenure, such as overseeing Mr. Trump’s withdrawal from the 2015 international nuclear deal with Iran, reached under former President Obama, and scaling back American support for the United Nations.

Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin, national security adviser John Bolton and Vice President Mike Pence, left to right, looking on as President Trump said the U.S. intends to withdraw from the Iran nuclear agreement at the White House in Washington on May 8, 2018. Photo: jonathan ernst/Reuters

But his consolidation of authority during his first months in the job irked other administration officials, who said he and his National Security Council weren’t acting in their traditional role of honest brokers in coordinating the administration’s national security policies.

Long known in and outside government for his pugilistic style, Mr. Bolton also clashed with then-Chief of Staff John Kelly and with Kirstjen Nielsen, a former Homeland Security secretary, over how to handle migrants on the border with Mexico.

Mr. Bolton saw an unusual check on his authority early on when the office of first lady Melania Trump took the unusual step of publicly calling for the removal from the White House of deputy national security adviser Mira Ricardel —Mr. Bolton’s handpicked No. 2. Ms. Ricardel subsequently left the National Security Council.

Mr. Bolton—a former ambassador to the United Nations under President George W. Bush who also served in the administrations of Republicans Ronald Reagan and George H.W. Bush—has been an influential force in conservative politics. He endorses dozens of candidates every election year, sending them money directly through his political committee and making independent expenditures promoting them through his super PAC.

President Trump’s first national security adviser, Mike Flynn, was forced out after 24 days amid questions about contacts with Russian officials, and he subsequently pleaded guilty to lying to the Federal Bureau of Investigation. The next adviser, Lt. Gen. H.R. McMaster, stepped aside after criticism that he wasn’t pursuing Mr. Trump’s agenda vigorously enough.

Mr. Bolton’s abrupt ouster spurred strong reaction on Capitol Hill, where lawmakers have long split on the contentious policy adviser.

“I’m very very unhappy to hear that he’s leaving,” said Sen. Mitt Romney (R., Utah). “It is a huge loss in my opinion for the administration and for the nation to no longer have John Bolton at the table on matters of foreign policy.”

“His experience in foreign policy, his point of view, wasn’t the same as everyone else in the room. That’s why you wanted him there,” Mr. Romney said. “The fact that he was a contrarian from time to time was an asset, not a liability.”

Sen. Rand Paul (R., Ky.), who has a long history of opposing U.S. military intervention overseas, applauded the decision.

“The chances for war worldwide go down exponentially with him out of the White House,” Mr. Paul said.

Sen. Brian Schatz (D., Hawaii) said, “I think it’s great.”

Sen. Lindsey Graham, (R., S.C.), a supporter of Mr. Bolton, said the national security adviser wasn’t working out for Mr. Trump.

“It’s clear to me that the relationship had soured,” Mr. Graham said. “I hope he’ll pick a national security adviser that he has confidence in, but I appreciate John Bolton and I think he sees the world as a dangerous place.”

Mr. Graham said he didn’t know the end was coming for Mr. Bolton, but he had heard it might be related to the controversy over inviting the Taliban to Camp David.

“I knew there were some concerns about the Taliban meeting but I didn’t know for sure,” Mr. Graham said. “He gave the president his honest opinion and it’s time for him to move on.”

—Lindsay Wise, Natalie Andrews and Siobhan Hughes contributed to this article.

description: The president dismissed John Bolton, who has disagreed with him on several foreign policy issues.
